awd_titl_txt: Explicit Moduli Problems and Arithmetic Statistics
awd_abstract_narration:
One way to study complicated objects in mathematics is to compute simpler "invariants" of the object, which express some (but not complete) information about the object. This project studies invariants arising from objects associated to sets of polynomial equations, and how certain invariants are distributed when considering large families of these objects. For example, if the invariant is an integer, one may ask how likely the integer is, say, zero for a "random" object. Such results then translate into a better understanding of the initial equations and their behavior.

This project involves problems using explicit constructions of moduli spaces in algebraic geometry, as well as applications of these parametrizations to obtain statistical information about arithmetic invariants, using methods ranging from classical algebraic geometry constructions to Lie theory and sieve techniques from analytic number theory. The PI proposes to work on finding correspondences between orbits of representations of algebraic groups and moduli spaces of curves, abelian varieties, and other varieties.  The PI also plans to use these explicit descriptions of the moduli spaces, along with techniques from the geometry of numbers and analytic number theory, to study the asymptotic growth of arithmetic data related to the parametrizations.  Such applications include studying the distributions of the ideal class groups of number fields, bounding the average rank of elliptic curves, and finding densities of curves with a given number of points.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on studying fundamental objects of classical interest in number theory, such as number fields and elliptic curves, and their so-called invariants, in infinite well-behaved families. One facet of the project was to determine ways to classify such objects with algebraic constructions, i.e., to describe the parameter or moduli spaces of these objects using algebraic geometry and representation theory. Another goal of the project was to use more analytic methods to study the objects, once classified, and to understand the distribution of their invariants.

A number of results were obtained in all of these directions during this NSF grant. For example, in joint work with Levent Alpoge, we gave a new bound on the number of integral points on elliptic curves over the rational numbers using only the rank of the curve and the primes dividing the discriminant to high order; this led to a bound on the second moment (and some higher moments) on the number of integral points on elliptic curves. These results, suitably generalized, also apply to S-integral points on elliptic curves over number fields.

In joint work with Matt Satriano, we studied algebraic constructions (Galois closures) with an application to Hermitian representations whose orbits classify interesting algebro-geometric objects.  In joint work with Max Lieblich, we showed that Brauer classes of fields are always split by torsors under abelian varieties. This question was motivated by a similar (still open) question for genus one curves, which seems related to algebraic constructions of moduli spaces useful for counting Selmer elements of elliptic curves.

In joint work with Tom Fisher and Jennifer Park, we studied the Hasse local-to-global principle for hypersurfaces in products of projective spaces, and in particular, computed the proportion of certain genus one curves that are everywhere locally soluble. This is closely linked to joint work with Manjul Bhargava, where we show that many of those genus one curves fail the Hasse principle, thus giving many elements of the Tate-Shafarevich group.
This project led to many collaborations and projects with researchers at different stages of their careers, including undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers. Several students and postdoctoral fellows were also supported in various ways by this grant.

During the period of this grant, we made significant progress towards the goals of this project, and I and my collaborators and students are extremely grateful to the NSF for supporting this project that helped shed light on important problems in number theory and arithmetic geometry, especially related to problems in arithmetic statistics and the study of rational points.
